title: How to Make Pickled Watermelon Rind

steps.headline: Cut the watermelon and scoop out the flesh.
steps.description: Place a 5 pounds (2.3 kg) watermelon on a cutting board and use a chef's knife to cut it in half. Cut the halves in half so you get quarters. Then scoop away the flesh of the melon leaving about 1/4 to 1/2 in (3 to 6 mm) of flesh next to the rind. You can eat the watermelon flesh or use it in another recipe.

steps.headline: Use a knife to peel away the green from the rind.
steps.description: Carefully slice off all of the green from the outside of the watermelon rind and discard it. You'll be left with large wedges of pale rind that are ready for cutting and pickling. If you leave the dark green on the rind, it will be tough and bitter if you pickle it. If you're having trouble slicing away the green part, use a vegetable peeler.

steps.headline: Cut the watermelon rind into 1 in (2.5 cm) chunks.
steps.description: Use a chef's knife to cut the rind wedges into long strips that are 1 in (2.5 cm) wide. Then turn the strips 90-degrees and cut them into squares that are 1 in (2.5 cm) wide. Try to make the rind squares even so you get uniform pieces.

steps.headline: Mix the vinegar, water, sugar, ginger, salt, and spices.
steps.description: Set a saucepan on the stove and pour 1 cup (240 ml) of apple cider vinegar and 1 cup (240 ml) of water into it. Stir in 3/4 cup (150 g) of sugar, 1/4 cup (55 g) of candied or crystallized ginger chunks, 4 teaspoons (24 g) of kosher salt, 1 teaspoon (1.8 g) of red pepper flakes, 1 teaspoon (2 g) of allspice berries, and 1 star anise pod. If you can't find candied or crystallized ginger, substitute fresh peeled ginger root.

steps.headline: Boil the mixture for 60 seconds.
steps.description: Turn the burner to medium-high and stir it occasionally. The mixture should become syrupy as the sugar dissolves and it comes to a boil. Let it boil for 60 seconds.

steps.headline: Add the watermelon rind and bring the mixture back to a boil.
steps.description: Carefully put the watermelon rind pieces into the saucepan and stir so they're coated with the mixture. Heat the watermelon in the syrup until the mixture comes back to a boil. Don't drop the watermelon pieces into the hot syrup or the syrup could splash you.

steps.headline: Turn off the burner and cool the watermelon for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Move the saucepan to a cool burner so the watermelon cools faster. It will absorb flavors and soften a little as it rests.

steps.headline: Transfer the watermelon and syrup to a jar and cover it.
steps.description: Once the watermelon has cooled a bit, spoon them into a 2-quart (1.9 liter) jar and pour the syrup mixture in it. Screw the lid onto the jar. It can help to use a canning funnel and ladle so you don't make as big of a mess.

steps.headline: Rest the watermelon at room temperature for 1 1/2 hours.
steps.description: Leave the covered watermelon rind to sit at room temperature. It will continue to absorb the flavors of the syrup.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the watermelon rind and use it within 1 month.
steps.description: Move the jar of watermelon rind to the refrigerator and let it sit overnight. Then you can begin eating the watermelon rind. Consider serving pickled watermelon rind with grilled foods or on salads. Since these watermelon rinds haven't been canned, it's important to eat them within 1 month of putting them in the refrigerator.

steps.headline: Cut the watermelon and remove the flesh.
steps.description: Put a 4 pounds (1.8 kg) watermelon on a cutting board cut it in half with a large chef's knife. Then cut each of the halves in half to make quarters. Use a spoon to scoop away the flesh of the melon, but leave about 1/4 in (3 mm) of flesh next to the rind. Save the watermelon flesh for another recipe or eat it.

steps.headline: Peel off the green from the rind.
steps.description: Use a knife or vegetable peeler to carefully slice off the green from the outside of the watermelon rind. Throw it away so you're left with large wedges of pale rind. Don't leave the dark green on the rind because it will make your pickled watermelon tough.

steps.headline: Cut the watermelon rind into 1 x 1/2 in (2.5 by 1.3 cm) chunks.
steps.description: Take your chef's knife and cut the rind wedges into strips that are 1 in (2.5 cm) wide. Turn the strips 90-degrees and cut them into pieces that are 1/2 in (1.3 cm) wide. Try to make the rectangles even so you get uniform pieces. You should end up with about 4 cups (550 g) of watermelon pieces.

steps.headline: Heat the water and 2 tablespoons (36 g) of the salt to boiling.
steps.description: Pour 8 cups (1.9 l) of water into a large pot on the stove. Stir in 2 tablespoons (36 g) of the coarse salt and turn the burner to high. Heat the salt water until it comes to a boil. To make the water boil faster, put the lid on the pot and watch for steam escaping from under the lid.

steps.headline: Add the watermelon rind and boil it for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Carefully put the watermelon rind pieces into the pot with boiling water. Keep the lid off of the pot and boil the rind until it becomes tender. Then turn off the burner.

steps.headline: Strain the watermelon rind and transfer it to a bowl.
steps.description: Place a colander into a sink and slowly pour the watermelon rind into it. The salt water will drain off into the sink. Scoop the watermelon rind into a large bowl and set it aside.

steps.headline: Mix the remaining salt, sugar, vinegar, and spices.
steps.description:
Put a large saucepan on the stove and pour in 1 ⁄4 cups (300 ml) of apple cider vinegar. Stir in the remaining:
2 teaspoons (12 g) of coarse salt
2 cups (400 g) of sugar
8 whole cloves
8 whole black peppercorns
2 cinnamon sticks
1/2 teaspoon (1.5 g) of pickling spice
1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of ground allspice
1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of ground ginger.

steps.headline: Bring the spice mixture to a boil.
steps.description: Turn the burner to medium-high and stir the spice mixture frequently. Heat the mixture until it comes to a boil and the sugar dissolves. Stir frequently to prevent the mixture from sticking and burning.

steps.headline: Pour the spiced syrup over the watermelon rinds and put a plate on top.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and pour the spiced syrup into the bowl with the watermelon rinds. To keep the rinds submerged, put a large plate over the bowl. If the rinds are submerged without the plate, simply cover the bowl with plastic wrap.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the watermelon rinds for at least 8 hours.
steps.description: Put the bowl with the plate on top into the refrigerator. Chill the watermelon rinds for at least 8 hours or overnight. The rinds will absorb the flavors as they rest.

steps.headline: Strain the watermelon rind syrup into a saucepan.
steps.description: Remove the bowl of watermelon rinds from the refrigerator. Set a fine mesh strainer over a saucepan and pour the watermelon rinds with syrup into the strainer. The syrup will drain into the saucepan. Put the watermelon rinds back into the bowl that you chilled them in.

steps.headline: Bring the syrup to a boil and pour it over the rinds.
steps.description: Turn the burner on to medium-high and stir the syrup occasionally. Heat the syrup until it comes to a boil and then turn off the burner. Pour it over the rinds in the large bowl.

steps.headline: Cover and refrigerate the watermelon rinds overnight.
steps.description: Cover the bowl and put the rinds in the refrigerator. Then take the rinds out and strain them again. Boil the liquid 1 final time and pour it over the rinds again. Chill the rinds and use them once they're cold. Keep the pickled watermelon rind in the refrigerator in a covered jar. Use it within 2 to 4 weeks.
